docs.lead_paragraph: LAST month, the privately held Swiss drug company, Hoffmann-LaRoche, dealt a harsh blow to its American work force: Disappointed by the flow of new products here and preparing for the imminent expiration of its lucrative patent on Valium, the company said it would lay off 1,000 employees, more than 12 percent of its American payroll. It was a highly unusual move for a company that for years towered well above its competitors. But the meaning was clear: After years of profits so fat that they immunized the $30 billion American pharmaceutical industry against economic downturns, the big drug companies have suddenly found themselves mired in the same sort of troubles that have plagued less-glamorous industries for years. Spiraling imports, legislative changes and new competition at home and abroad have struck hard. And with new blockbuster products harder and harder to come by, America's supremacy as the world's premier maker and seller of prescription drugs could be in jeopardy. ''The pressure is on us, if we're going to survive at the growth rates we had in the past,'' said John J. Horan, chairman of Merck & Company, one of the world's pacesetting pharmaceutical houses.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Internal Revenue Service has a heart,'' says the accounting firm of Arthur Young & Company in its guide to completing 1984 tax returns. ''Tax law is fairly generous in defining medical expenditures that may be deducted from your income.'' To illustrate the ''heart'' of the I.R.S.: Virtually any payment you have made to someone who has diagnosed, treated, or prevented an illness, including mental illness, is deductible, regardless of whether the preson who provided the service was a physician, chiropractor or Christian Science practitioner. You can also deduct the cost of surgery and of procedures ranging from face lifts and hair transplants to electrolysis. And this past year, the Internal Revenue Service ruled that the cost of special schools for disabled or emotionally disturbed children may be deducted as well as part of the ''founder's fee'' that elderly people may be required to pay before they enter a retirement home.
